citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
On two occasions, the registrant accepted dogs for transport more than 6 hours before the scheduled departure time of a
flight. The dogs are as follows:
** One adult dog on August 1, 2025 (Waybill #157-40327431). The flight was scheduled to depart at 7:20 PM. Per the
registrant's check-in form, the dog was accepted at 12:12 PM, over 7 hours before the scheduled departure.
** Two adult dogs on August 5, 2025 (Waybill #157-63556032). The flight was scheduled to depart at 7:20 PM. The
inspector witnessed the animals' acceptance at 12:36 PM, about 6.75 hours before the scheduled departure.
Employees reported that this facility regularly accepts dogs and cats for transport over 6 hours before the scheduled flight
departure.
Accepting an animal more than 6 hours before its scheduled departure time extends their time confined in transport
enclosures, which can increase increase risk of adverse health and welfare effects of animal transport.
Carriers must not accept a dog or cat for transport in commerce more than 4 hours before the scheduled departure time
of the primary conveyance on which the animal is to be transported. However, a carrier or intermediate handler may
agree with anyone consigning a dog or cat to extend this time by up to 2 hours.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.14(a) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
On two occasions, the registrant accepted dogs for transport more than 6 hours before the scheduled departure time of a 
flight. The dogs are as follows: 
 
** One adult dog on August 1, 2025 (Waybill #157-40327431). The flight was scheduled to depart at 7:20 PM. Per the 
registrant's check-in form, the dog was accepted at 12:12 PM, over 7 hours before the scheduled departure.  
** Two adult dogs on August 5, 2025 (Waybill #157-63556032). The flight was scheduled to depart at 7:20 PM. The 
inspector witnessed the animals' acceptance at 12:36 PM, about 6.75 hours before the scheduled departure. 
 
Employees reported that this facility regularly accepts dogs and cats for transport over 6 hours before the scheduled flight 
departure. 
 
Accepting an animal more than 6 hours before its scheduled departure time extends their time confined in transport 
enclosures, which can increase increase risk of adverse health and welfare effects of animal transport. 
 
Carriers must not accept a dog or cat for transport in commerce more than 4 hours before the scheduled departure time 
of the primary conveyance on which the animal is to be transported. However, a carrier or intermediate handler may 
agree with anyone consigning a dog or cat to extend this time by up to 2 hours. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
